renderEngine

Class RenderInputWindow

  • java.lang.Object
    • renderEngine.RenderInputWindow

  • public class RenderInputWindow
extends java.lang.Object

    This class functions as the main display for Arsia. It generates a render window that also handles user input. This is achieved by using the underlying GLFW library in tandem with the OpenGL pipeline.

    To properly use this class, follow the general order of operations:
    1. Construct the display, specifying width, height, and window title name
    2. Make a call to the initializing method
    3. Query the state of the window for the main game loop
    4. In the main game loop, while the state of the window is open:
      1. Handle user input
      2. Make a call to prepare the rendering engine
      3. Finally, render the specified RawModel(s)
    5. Clean up resources once the window is closed
    Author:
    Matthew L. Roy

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      RenderInputWindow(int windowWidth, int windowHeight, java.lang.String windowName)
      This constructor just sets up the passed variables for the initializing method.

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Concrete Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      void cleanUp()
      Frees up resources as it relates to the GLFW callback methods and display window, while clearing the error stream for GLFW.

      Performs a low-level call to the GLFW pipeline to handle events.
      void init()
      This method initializes the backend hooks for the GLFW display, as well as sets up the input handler (by using callback methods).
      boolean isClosed()
      Returns the state of the GLFW window, specifically if it is closed or open.
      void prepare()
      This method prepares the GLFW API for rendering.
      void render(RawModel model)
      Must be called immediately after prepare().

    • Constructor Detail

      • RenderInputWindow

        public RenderInputWindow(int windowWidth,
                         int windowHeight,
                         java.lang.String windowName)
        This constructor just sets up the passed variables for the initializing method. Make a call immediately to init() once the constructor has been called.
        Parameters:
        windowWidth - the width, in pixels, of this display window
        windowHeight - the height, in pixels, of this display window
        windowName - the name in the title bar of this display window

    • Method Detail

      • init

        public void init()
        This method initializes the backend hooks for the GLFW display, as well as sets up the input handler (by using callback methods). This method should be called immediately after RenderInputWindow(int, int, String) construction.

      • handleInput

        public void handleInput()
        Performs a low-level call to the GLFW pipeline to handle events. Specifically, input is handled in this call.

      • prepare

        public void prepare()
        This method prepares the GLFW API for rendering. This method is critical for LWJGL's interpretation with GLFW's OpenGL context, or any context that is managed externally. LWJGL detects the context that is current in the current thread, creates the GLCapabilities instance and makes the OpenGL bindings available for use. Also sets the clear color to the desired RGB configuration. Make a call to render(RawModel) after calling prepare.

      • render

        public void render(RawModel model)
        Must be called immediately after prepare(). This method renders the model to the display with the correct position. Uses the model's Vertex Array Object (VAO) and then uses the Vertex Buffer Object (VBO) at VAO attribute position 0, which coincides with vertex positions.
        Parameters:
        model - the specified model to be rendered to the display

      • cleanUp

        public void cleanUp()
        Frees up resources as it relates to the GLFW callback methods and display window, while clearing the error stream for GLFW. Call this method when isClosed() returns true.

      • isClosed

        public boolean isClosed()
        Returns the state of the GLFW window, specifically if it is closed or open. Make sure to call cleanUp() after this method returns true, indicating that the display has been closed.
        Returns:
        the current state of the GLFW window, whether it is closed or not
